FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1904..

div.head: ANGLO-FRENCH FRIENDSHIP
div.p: Yesterday the French Parliament entered on the discussion of the report of M. Deloncle on the Anglo-French Convention. It was pure- ly an accident that there has been delay in proceeding to ratification. On our side of the Channel that stage did not receive Parlia- mentary accomplishment until the very end of last Session, while in France time for doing so could not be either found or made, despite M. Delcassé's strenuous endeavours to hurry up the Chamber. Happily, there was-as there deserved to be-such a strong conviction of good faith and sincerity on both sides that the outside world came to regard the Convention as in actual being and opera-

tion. Neither in the United Kingdom nor elsewhere was there ever the faintest doubt that when the Chamber re-assembled it would take the matter in hand with all possible dis- patch. That expectation is now fulfilled, and too great credit could not be given to M. Cambon and M. Delcassé for the patience and perseverance with which they helped Lord Lansdowne to smooth away outstanding difficulties. But they could have done little or nothing had not French feeling at large expressed itself unmistakably in favour of strengthening and extending the entente between the neighbouring nations. The French Colonial party having bestowed its blessing on. the concordat diplomacy had an easy labour in giving the finishing touches to the New- foundland Agreement. Here, again, it is only fair to admit that M. Deloncle has full right to claim the renunciation by France of an irritating clause of the Treaty of Utrecht as an "important concession." It is of that character, unquestionably, and although an equivalent has been given by Great Britain elsewhere, the surrender by France of such very ancient rights and privileges denotes genuine goodwill towards England.

div.head:
Port Arthur
PRECARIOUS POSITION
div.p: Later advices confirm that the Japanese have gained such an advantage at Port Arthur that the main defences must fall when attacked, although Tiger's Tail Fort will still be defensible for another month.
(Reuter.)
Unprecedentedly enthusiastic celebrations took place throughout Japan in honour of the Emperor's birthday. The Emperor reviewed two divisions in full war equipment here. (R.)
On the occasion of his birthday the Mikado gave a dinner to the Diplomatic Corps. He said that he regretted that peace was not yet restored.
(Havas.)

div.head:
ANGLO-FRENCH CONVENTION.
DEBATE IN FRENCH CHAMBER.
div.p: The Chamber of Deputies has begun the debate on an interpellation regarding the Anglo-French Convention. MM. Deloncle and Deschanel spoke.
(Havas.)

div.head: Carlton Hotel
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh
First class Hotel. Newly Built. Sea breezes, Dry air. Near tramway station, the promenade, and Nustapha Parha Barracks, Garden, Lawn Townis. Good cuisine, Moderate charges, Open all year round
C. AQUILINA, Proprietor. (Late of Thos Cook & Sons); also General Manager, Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan.

div.head:
NORTH SEA OUTRAGE.
INQUEST ON VICTIMS
BALTIC FLEET SHADOWED.

div.p: Great Britain proposes that the International Commission shall consist of four delegates appointed by herself, Russia, France, and the United States, together with a fifth selected by these four, and that the meeting shall be held in Paris
(Reuter.)

At the instance of Counsel for Government, the Coroner's jury at Hull returned a verdict simply to the effect that the deceased were found killed by a shot fired from the Russian warships without warning or provocation.
The Morning Post has reason to believe that arrangements have been made for the British squadrons to shadow the Baltic Fleet throughout the voyage by both routes.
(Reuter.)
Four Russian battleships passed the mouth of the Tagus closely followed by four British cruisers, doubtless part of Admiral Walker's division.
(Reuter.)
Admiral Rodjestvensky has arrived. He will leave again immediately.
(Havas)
Admiral Rodjestvensky and four battleships have arrived here.
(Reuter.)
Witnesses at the inquest emphatically declared that no torpedo-boats were present. The four Russian officers who were detained at Vigo arrived at Paris, and proceeded to St. Petersburg.
(Reuter.)

div.head: THE GIBRALTAR DEMONSTRATION.
div.p: The proceedings at Gibraltar last Tuesday remain unexplained beyond the suggestion that they were in continuance of the mobilisation manœuvres.
(Reuter.)

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE-
div.p: 106 pilgrims have arrived from Constantinople and are leaving next week for Jeddah, via Suez.

div.head: KING'S BIRTHDAY.-
div.p: The usual King's Birthday parade will be held at Mustapha next Wednesday at 10 am. THE BRINDISI MAIL (outward) will be made up at the G.P.O., Alexandria, and despatched at 8.30 am. on Monday.

div.head: STEAMER PURCHASE-
div.p: Mr. Andriadis has purchased the S.S. Werda from the Coastguards Administration for the sum of £700.

div.head: QUARANTINE
div.p: restrictions are now applied to arrivals in Egyptian ports from Broach, in consequence of plague existing there.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL SOCIETY OF MEDICINE-
div.p: On Saturday next the Khedivial Society of Medicine will meet at 9.30 p.m. at the Cercle Artistique.

div.head: DRAMATIC PERFORMANCE-
div.p: On Sunday next the Italian Dramatic Society of Cairo will give a performance of I Disonesti, drama in 3 acts by Rosetti.

div.head: PARLAR DOGS-
div.p: Stray, and ownerless dogs found in the Ramleh and Minet-el-Bassal districts tomorrow night will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: THE NILE IN 1904.-
div.p: The title of Sir William Willcocks's book, the publication of which we announced in yesterday's issue, is "The Nile in 1904."

div.head: NATIONAL BANK-
div.p: Mr. E. Crewe has been appointed agent, Mr. E. Wenger accountant, and Mr. A. F. Carasso cashier of the National Bank's new branch in the Mousky, Cairo, which was opened on the 1st inst.

div.head: IRRIGATION DEPT.
div.p: Mr. Morcom, of the Irrigation Department, has been transferred from Alexandria to the 1st Circle. He will occupy the post of director of works in that Circle, in succession to Mr. Lambton.

div.head: SOCIAL ITEMS-
div.p: According to the latest statistics, it is anticipated that this winter the British colony at Cairo will be augmented by eighteen brides, including those who have already arrived since the summer.

div.head: THE SCIPLINI CASE-
div.p: Me. Fornario has presented to the clerk of the Italian Consular Court the motives of the appeal lodged against the judgment condemning M. L. Sciplini to five months' imprisonment for involuntary homicide.

div.head: THE BIBER OUTRAGE
div.p: The director of the sagar factory at Bibeb, who was recently fired on and slightly wounded, has informed the police that be suspects one Mohamed Abdallah, who lives in an ezbeh quite close to the factory. Mohamed Abdallah has therefore been arrested.

div.head: "THE CYPRUS JOURNAL"
div.p: for October contains some interesting “Notes on Malarial Fever and How to Avoid It," "Hints on Cow Calving," "How Seeds Germinate," and other useful information, including statistics of the trade of the Island. The Journal is published at its offices in Nicosia.

div.head: The ALEXANDRIA PORTERA
div.p: The inaugural ceremony of the Mutual Benevolent Society of the Alexandria Porters will take place on Sawday next, the 6th inst., at 3 pm, at the headquarters of the society, opposite the lMinet-el-Bassal caracol. Ismail Hafez Bey is the president of the society.

div.head: POST OFFICE FRAUDS-
div.p: Mr. Boulad, an official of the Post Office Administration at Alexandria, has been seriously suspected of forging money orders to the extent of some thousands of francs. Some of the native papers have given exaggerated amounts. Mr. Boulad's whereabouts are not at present known.

div.head: DOGS POISONED-
CHARITY FETE-
div.p: The annual charity fête of the Conference de St. Vincent de Paul (house- to-house visitation) will take place at St. Catherine's Cathedral, Alexandria, on Sunday next, at 11 am. Low mass will be celebrated at that hour, and a special sermon will be preached by the Very Rev. Father Urbain- Marie de Mugron, vicar. A collection will be made on behalf of the charity by Mmes Pierre Girard and Alexandre de Zogheb.

div.head: PHARMACY REGULATIONS.
div.p: The following are the details of the examination which all vendors of poisonous substances must pass, in accordance with Article 12 of the new regulations, before obtaining the necessary authorisation to sell such substances

Candidates will be examined on the first Monday of every month at the offices of the Sanitary Administration, Cairo, in the hospitals at Alexandria and the other gouvernorats, and in the headquarters of the moudiriehs. They will be required
(1) to show their knowledge of the text of the new regulations with regard to the sale of poisonous substances;
(2) To be able to read and write at dictation the names of all the substances mentioned in the lists appended to the regulations;
(3) To show a perfect knowledge of metrical weights and measures;

(4) To be able to distinguish at least 15 of the following substances:- Cobalt (metallic) arsenic), arsenic acid realgar (red sulphate of arsenic), orpiment (yellow sulphide of arsenic), hydrocyanic acid, cyanide of potassium, bichloride of mercury, bisulphate of mercury, yellow oxide of mercury, red oxide of mercury, acetate of lead, sulphate of zinc, chloride of zine, acetate of copper, tartar antimony, phos phorus, chloroform, picric acide, oxalic acid;
(5) To explain the method (a) of employing the above-mentioned substances, (b) of bottling and labelling them, etc., etc.;

(6) To demonstrate their ability to keep registers of the sale of poisonous substances. Candidates satisfying the examiners will be entitled to receive a license to sell such substances, bat in no case will the license be granted till the Sanitary Department has satisfied itself that the shop or place of sale is well-aired, dry, and clean, and displays the name of the person licensed in legible charaoters on its front.
The first examination will be held on December 5, 1904.

div.head: TARDY TELEGRAMS.
div.p: Our Tantah Correspondent writes:-I had occasion a few days ago to complain about the delay in transmission of telegrams between here and Alexandria. Nothing seems to have been done as yet to remedy this inconvenience. During the last few days messages have taken about two hours in transmission from Alexandria, and many are the persons who have received telegrams advising them of friends passing through Tantah after the train with their friends had left! This is a serious state of things which should not be allowed to continue. It is to be hoped that we shall soon have the telephone line working, and then the Telegraph Department will see their receipts diminish appreciably in consequence of their lax methods.

div.head: GUM ARABIC EXPORTS.
div.p: The gum arabic exports during the month of September last amounted to 851,627 kilos, valued at LE 19,162, as compared with 602,579 kilos. and LE 13,560 in the same month last year, showing an increase of 249,048 kilos. and LE 5,602. The exports were divided among the different countries as follows- United Kingdom, LE. 9,177; Ger- mathy, LE 1,313; Austria-Hungary, LE 1,657; France, LE 695; Italy, LE 201; Turkey, LE 8; United States, LE 4,601; Belgium, LE. 1,143; other countries, LE. 367.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Menes arrived at Liverpool yesterday afternoon.
The Moss Hoer Seti sailed from Liverpool yrater day afternoon and is doe bere about the 17th lost, wish passengers, malls, and general cargo.
The Khedivial Mall S.S. Prince Abbas will leave Alexandria on Wedoraday for Pirnar, Beyrna, Mitylene, and Constantinople.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The inauguration of the new mosque at Dikaleh by the Khedive yesterday was attended by the Governor of Alexandria, the Director-General of the Wakfs Administration, and a number of native notables.
His Highness left Dikaleh at 1 p.m. and proceeded to Montazah.

H.H. the Khedive will arrive in Cairo at 11.30a.m. on Tuesday and will be received inside the station by a guard of honour consisting of 3 officers and 100 men detailed for the purpose from the 16th Battalion, with the battalion colour and the Cavalry Band. All officers of and above the rank of bimbashi who are not on duty at the time will attend- at the station at 11.15 am. On the arrival of his Highness a salute of 21 guns will be fired and another salute of as many guns will greet H.H. the Khedivah on her arrival at Koubbeh at 12.10 on the same morning.

div.head: QUEEN HATSHEPSU
div.p: Keen regret was felt throughout Egyptological circles when the announcement was made that the tomb of Queen Hatshepsu contained nothing but a large sarcophagus, when discovered and opened last winter, beneath the temple of Deir-el-Bahri. An American Egyptologist, just returning form Thebes, reports that be believes many other articles belonging to Hatshepsu were discovered and stolen by the native excavators, for he has already seen six exquisite alabaster ointment pots and seven delicate toilette knives bearing the full hieroglyphic name of this famous queen.
The sum of £100 was asked for each of these articles, but the amount is considered very excessive, as an alabaster jar, bearing the cartouche of King Seneferu, was sold a short time ago for £40.

Mr.Quibell, who has recently been transferred, as Inspector of Antiquities, to Upper Egypt, will undoubtedly soon be in possession of full facts concerning these treasures, and it is to be hoped that he may be able to secure them for the Cairo Museum.

div.head: THEFT OF SPECIE "GROUPS."
div.p: A Marseilles Contemporary of the 27th ulto. states:-50 groups," each containing 15,000 francs in pounds sterling, arrived at Marseilles from Paris yesterday. These "groups," which were forwarded by the Allard Bank, of Paris, were destined for the National Bank of Egypt, at Alexandria, and were to be embarked on board the S.S.. Congo, of the Messageries Maritimes. They were deposited in the sheds of the "gare, maritime," and this morning it was reported that six of the sacks had been stolen. The thieves had concealed themselves in the sheds and carried away the booty, after having made a hole in the partition which separated them from the street. No trace of the thieves has been found.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE
div.p: During the week ending yesterday, 33 deaths from bovine typhus were reported throughout Egypt, 32 of which were in Lower and 1 in Upper Egypt, as against 64 reported in the previous week, showing a decrease of 31. Since the beginning of the epidemic, the total number of deaths reported amounts to 146,515, distributed as follows:- Gouvernorate, 852; Lower Egypt, 53,538; Upper Egypt, 92,125. During the last week no new localities were reported infected. 139 inoculations with serum were made.

div.head: BUBONIC PLAGUE.
div.p: During the week ending yesterday 2 cases of bubonic plague were reported throughout Egypt. At present there are no cases under treatment in the country.

div.head: NILE TRIPS FOR RESIDENTS.
div.p: Residents of Egypt will no doubt be glad to be reminded of the fact that at the commencement of the Cairo season, for the first two or three sailings of their Nile steamers to Assouan, Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son generally make a special reduction for their benefit. The rates they are putting into operation for this season are, we understand, £25 instead of £50 for the tourist service by the sailings to Assouan ex Cairo on November 15 and 29 and December 6, and £15 instead of £22 for the express service by the sailings ex Cairo on November 4, 11, 18, and 25, and December 2, 5, and 9.

The tourist service is a voyage of 20 days, and the fare includes all sight-seeing expenses, it being a first-class service in every respect. The express service trip occupies 19 days, four days of which are spent at Assouan at the hotel there, and three days at Luxor. Doubtless, after the very hot summer which residents have experienced this year, many of the Government officials and others will wish to avail themselves of one of these sailings, and full information may be obtained at the company's offices

div.head: ALEXANDRIA CONSERVATOIRE.
div.p: The second annual "epreuve" of the pupils of the Alexandria Conservatoire, which took place last evening at the New Khedivial Hotel, was a great success. The programme was splendidly executed, the rendering of Schumann's Paradise and the Peri being a veritable triumph. We understand that the municipal authorities and consuls present expressed their readiness to support an institution which reflects such credit on their city. The hall last night was crammed, among the large audience present being H.E. the Governor.

div.head:
THE NADOURY MURDER.
CHARGE AGAINST AMADEA DISMISSED.
div.p: -The Greek consular authorities expect to authenticate the Hellenic nationality of Anastasi, who is suspected of complicity in the Nadoury murder. The documents are expected to arrive here from Constantinople on Mon- day next.

The "Chambre de Conseil" of the Italian Consular Court at Alexandria this morning dismissed the charge of complicity in the murder of the Pasha, brought against Amades Marini. The accused was defended by the advocate Gastone Levi Cuer.

div.head: THE CRETAN TRAGEDY.
div.p: The Hellenic nationality of Menegakis, who murdered Zakakis at the Pyramides Café at Alexandria, was authenticated to-day.Menegakis will therefore be handed over to the Greek consular authorities to-morrow morning.

div.head: EDEN THEATRE TRAGEDY.
div.p: The name of the murderer of the Italian at the Eden Music hall, Alexandria, is Simon Petro. He belongs to Sayma. This morning he was handed over to the Greek consular authorities.

div.head: THEWPIKIEH NILE NAVIGATION CO.
div.p: The collapse of this native concern and the extraordinary disclosures made by the liquidators of the company at the meeting of the shareholders and creditors which was held on the 10th ultimo still forms a topic of conversation in native circles. We understand that Menshawi Pasha has now offered to pay off all outstanding liabilities and take over the concern as it stands.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL BANK.
div.p: Yesterday, the Notarial Deed Office at the Alexandria Mixed Courts passed over 300 mortgage deeds granted by the Agricultural Bank of Egypt to the fellaheen.

div.head: NEW COLLEGE AT CAIRO.
div.p: The new girls' college to be built by the American Presbyterian Mission will be situated on the Boulevard Abbas, the new thoroughfare to be made from Kasr-el-Nil to Abbassieh, alongside the canal which is being filled up. The college will be half-way between Matarieh station and Abbassieh, and is to be erected on a plot of land purchased from Sakakini Pasha, 14,000 square metres in extent. This extensive site will allow of the erection of a fine large college to comprise three separate, buildings, viz, the dormitories and class-rooms, a science building, and a chapel or auditorium. The new college will be three stories high and will accommodate between 150 and 200 boarders, besides 200 day scholars. The works will commence as soon as the Nile will permit, and the contractors can commence the foundations. The Mission has so far in hand towards the total expenses of land and buildings 60,000 dollars, or about £12,000, of which half has been raised in America and between £600 and £700 in Egypt, and they hope that their many friends and old pupils in this country will come forward and help the good cause of native female education, irrespective of creed aid nationality, which has been carried on with such signal success for a long number of years by the Mission.

It is expected that the entire new buildings will be completed and ready for occupation in about a year and a half from the 1st January next. At present there are in the college in the Esbekieb quarter 96 boarders and about 200 day scholars, but many applications for the former class of pupils have to be refused on account of want of proper accommodation, and there are no means of enlarging the premises now in use.

div.head:
ST. ANDREW'S CHURCH, ALEXANDRIA.
EVENING SERVICE.
div.p: The Sacrament of the Lord's Supper will be celebrated in this church on Sunday next at 10.30 am. Visitors and friends are cordially invited.
An evening service will be held on Sunday at 6 pm. and will be continued every Sunday evening during the winter months.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE
div.p: There was last night a large audience at the Alhambra Theatre, and the performance given of L'Enfant du Miracle proved very successful, Mile Armande Leturc was particularly conspicuous in the part of Elise, and Mile Olga Bonin in that of Marguerite. Messrs. Silvestre, de Préfonds, Marmier and La Claverie were also good.

There will be no performance at the Alham bes to-night. Tomorrow evening, the "Archi mede Misuri" is announced to give an entertainment. On Sunday afternoon, there will be a musical matinée and balloon ascents, one of the balloons measuring 12 metres in height and 35 in circumference. In the evening there will be a variety entertainment.

div.head:
PASSENGER LISTS.
ARRIVALS
div.p: Le paquebot Memfi, de la Cie Florio-Rabat- tino, arrivé hier de Gênes avait à bord:

MM. Balucci, Alf. Imperato, Mane G. Ghigi et enfant, Rosati, S. Rosano, Dr. Canalini, G. Damolino, Taber Ben Morst, Moh. Ben Mahmoud, Giulio Banali, Mme J. A. Havari et fils, Arthur C. Fort, R. Ravani, Ch. Fischer, H. Levi, M. et Mme G. Armanini, Mme G. Rafina, et 44 passagers de 8me classe.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit – within certain necessary limits 00 free discussion.

div.head:
AN EGYPTIAN MINISTRY OF AGRICULTURE.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: Sir, The letter which appeared in your issue of the 2nd inst. upon the above subject invites favourable consideration at the hands of the authorities. Sometimes, unfortunately, the physicians of the body politic, through want of accurate diagnosis, prescribe the wrong remedy, or, dropping metaphor, criticism, honest and well-meaning though it be, fails of its effect through the writer's imperfect acquaintance with his subject. Nosuch charge can be laid at the door of a "Child of the Nile Valley," who is a precocious child indeed-a veritable infant prodigy, conversant especially with the "wheels within wheels" of the administrative machine, and especially where they are clogged and inefficient. Such letters as his and you have published of late not a few clearly indicate to the watchers in the "crow's nest" that a body of enlightened and well- informed opinion is growing up in Egypt which will courageously claim a bearing irrespective of the consequences. This is a most healthy sign of progress portending that an intelligent public is taking a greater intérest than here- tofore in the affairs of the country. Such opinion, in the near future, will manifest itself in the initiation of useful reforms upon popular lines, and the suppression of abuses which necessarily occur with increasing frequency when a government is left to itself unchecked by non-official and unprejudiced criticism.
I am, eto,

div.head:
THE CAIRO STREETS.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: Sir, In view of the many allusions in your columns to the disgraceful condition of the main streets of Cairo, I think it is high time the Tanzim authorities were "hauled over the coals" for their apparent lack of supervision. As a matter of fact, there is no supervision at all, and there is in addition the fact that their alackness in causing very serious inconvenience and loss to the tradespeople in certain districts. It is even said that some action is contemplated to sue the Government for such loss to business. I may mention that on the 3rd inst. the work on the road at Ataba el-Khadra, opposite the Wakfs buildings, was commenced and was promised to be completed in 3 or 4 days at the outside. It is not yet finished. It appears there may not be any reliance on the word of the authorities.

To go further, Clot Bey-the most frequented thoroughfare in Cairo has been in a to- tally impassable state for months; first one side was hauled up for water pipes, then the other for gas or something else. Now one side is completely impassable; it is all dug up for a depth of about 25 centimetres -this is presumably for the new lines and the asphalte that have been promised. When, oh! when will our streets be fit to be used again?
I am, etc.,

div.head:
ABBAS HELMY THEATRE
"LA FORZA DEL DESTINO."
div.p: The production last evening of this favourite old opera of Verdi was an unqualified success. Each of the artistes was successful in his or her role, the choruses were, as usual, given with a finish not far from perfection and showed signs of very careful training, the orchestra was perfect, and the attention paid to minor detail throughout the opera was highly commendable. Surely such excellence as was displayed on every side is deserving of more liberal support than it has hitherto received, and it is to be hoped that Alexandrians will not fail to recognise that if such excellent fare is to be provided at so moderate a price, they must come forward and support the efforts of the enterprising management who are catering so well for their amusement and pleasure. What could have been more delightfully rendered than the several numbers in the second act, where Signs Popovici and Sig. Baldelli sang with such magnificent effect, and were so admirably supported by the members of the chorus, noticeably in the prayer song! Indeed, the whole of the music in the second act was throughout so artistically rendered, and such depth of feeling was displayed, that without doubt the audience would willingly have listened to its repetition from beginning to end. Improvement in this net particularly, we think, could hardly have been possible. The Donna Leonors of Signorinas H. Popovici was a charming impersonation and captivated the sympathies of her audience im- mediately. In addition to being an accomplished vocalist, this lady possessos histrionic ability of a high order. Signs. Cecchi was very sue- cessful in the role of Preziosilla and met with some hearty applause in the third act. As Padre Guardiano Francescano, Signor Mariano Baldelli was perfect, his magnificent voice being heard to great advantage. Sig. Pietro Venerandi, as Don Alvaro, and Sig. Cattadori, as Don Carlo, were equally successful in their respective characters, and secured rounds of well-merited applause throughout the opera, while Signor Barrione, as Fra Militone, was decidedly amusing. The minor characters were in good hands, and the opera went with a swing from start to finish.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Countess of Londesborough and her daughters are coming out to Egypt in January and will make a prolonged stay at the Mens House Hotel. -
Lord Londesborough, who is coming to Egypt in December, will stay at the Sayoy Hotel and will then proceed to Mens to rejoin the Countess.
Colonel Sir William and Lady Bisset are due at Mens House Hotel on the 20th inst.
The Victoria, which is due at Port Said next Tuesday, is bringing for Egypt, among others, Lord and Lady Newport, Lord Parrer. Lady Rogers, and Miss E. Gorst.

Lord Parrer, who arrives on Tuesday in order to preside over the Commission appointed to enquire into the administration of the State railways, succeeded as second baren five years ago when he was in the neighbourhood of forty. The creation dates to six years before that date, when it was bestowed on Sir Thomas Henry Farrer in somewhat tardy acknowledgment of his six-and-thirty years' work at the Board of Trade, of which he became in 1850 Assistant Marine Secretary and was subsequently appointed Permanent Secretary. The present baron, though he has not been conspicuous in public life, is a man of very sound qualities and great abilities He is a nephew of the Dowager Countess of Iddesleigh and of Lady Hobhouse, and he celebrated his forty-fifth birthday last week.
As far as is at present settled, Sir Ernest Cassel is expected to arrive in Egypt about the middle of January.

A marriage has been arranged between Captain Dick-Canyngham, 21st (Empress of India's) Lancers, second son of the late Sir Robert Dick-Cunyngham, Bart, of Prestonfield, and Lady Dick-Canyngham, Polafield, Cheltenham, and Beatrice Eleanor, eldest daughter of the late Captain Charles Lousada, Shelburne Hall, Cheltenham.
A marriage has been arranged, and will take place at Alexandria on Sunday next, between the daughter of Fakhry Bey, Beyrout, and Ahmed Mohsen Bey, brother of Hassan Pasha Mohsen.
Mr. A. L Webb returned to Cairo from Assouan yesterday evening.
Mr. E. Tillard, of the Quarantine Board, has been appointed chief architect to the Prisons Department.
A telegram from Paris announces the death of the younger son of Boghos Pasha Nabar, at school.
Mr. H. Aspinall returned to Cairo yesterday.

We greatly regret to record the death of Mr. C. C. Buchanan, of the Standard Assurance Company, who succumbed to typhoid fever at the Anglo-American Hospital yesterday afternoon. The funeral of the deceased took place this morning at 10.30 at the British Cemetery, Old Cairo.

div.head: LETTRE DE CONSTANTINOPLE
div.p: Akof Pacha, Vice-Président de la section législative du Conseil d'Etat, avait été envoyé à Paris pour contrôler la confection des titres de la Dette Unifiée. Le Syndicat, en se chargeant de l'unification avait pro- mis à la Porte un prêt de L.T. 2,500,00 qu'il prenait à option jusqu'au 31 décembre de la présente année 1904): jusqu'en octobre de cette même année, le Syndicat avancerait au Trésor L.T. 800,000 et si le 31 décembre le Syndicat renonçait à l'opération, le gouvernement ture devrait lui rembourser les L.T. 800,000 avancées. Dans tous les cas, le revenu des nouveaux timbres, affecté en principe au service de la Dette Unifiée, devait être réservé pour le moment aux intérêts et à l'amortissement des L.T. 800,000, ei-dessus mentionnées. Or, peu après son arrivée à Paris, Akof Pacha est entré en pourparlers avec un français, ancien Directeur du Crédit Lyonnais à Constantinople et attaché aujourd'hui à je ne sais quelle banque parisienne; ces pourparlers avaient pour objet un emprunt de fr. 35,000,000, garanti par le revenu des nouveaux timbres.

L'affaire marchait et était même sur le point d'aboutir, lorsque le Syndicat de l'unification en a été avisé; celui-ci a aussitôt écrit à la Dette Publique et à la Banque Ottomane pour qu'elles eussent à empêcher cette aliénation de gage. Bloch et Berger se sont immédiatement rendus au Palais où ils ont assez durement parlé à Tahsin Pacha, lui conseillant de prévenir le Sultan que ni le Syndicat ni la Dette ne laisseraient s'accomplir cet acte d'escroquerie (dolend-rdjelik). Le lendemain, lo Conseil de la Dette Publique adressait à la Porte et au Malich une protestation poor garantie relativement à l'unification et à l'emprunt projeté de 1904; il n'hésitait pas à recourir à la loi, si le gouvernement ne lui versait pas le revenu des timbres,réservé au service de ces deux opérations financières. Akof Pacba a été rappelé Sa mission se bornait à négocier l'emprunt de 35,000,000-en offrant la garantie des nouveaux timbres.

Le négociant Cantavi Zaté réclame LE 150,000, montant des fournitures qu'il a faites au corps d'armée de la Macédoine. On ne le paie pas depuis longtemps et il ne sait plus par où passer. La semaine dernière, il s'est rendu à la Commission financière qui siège deux fois par semaine. au Palais, il a supplié qu'on lui donnât de l'argent, faisant remarquer que le groupe de sa créance provenait des farines qu'il avait fournies à crédit, au corps d'armée de la Macédoine, alors que ni à Constantinople ni à Salonique le gouvernement ne pouvait en trouver un ese autrement qu'au comp-. tant. Il n'a rien obtenu. Deux jours après il ne payait plus ses traites. Un journal ayant annoncé sa faillite, la Porte obligeait tous les journaux de la ville à donner un dément à cette nouvelle, démenti quie démontre que les créanciers de Cantavi Zadé avaient consenti à un délai pour le paiement de leurs traités et que son actif dépassait son pasif It le dépassers, si le gouvernement le paie.

En attendant, il est à l'état latent de faillite. Un autre fournisseur, Ismail Effin- di, réclame L.T. 70,000; on ne lai paie rien d à lui non plus, ainsi qu'à bien d'autres. D'après mes informations, pour pouvoir payer les dettes les plas eric sardes ef aller un peu de l'avant, il faudrait au moins au minimum L.T. 1,500,000. Où les trouvera- t-on? La seule rentrée que je vois sont les L.T. 350,000 que va fournir la concession du Câble télégraphique de Constantinople à Kustendje, accordée aux Allemands. H. P.

div.head: CORRESPONDANCE
div.p: nous n’assumons jamais la responsabilité des opinions exprimées par nos correspondants, mais nous désirons dans un esprit de loyauté permettre– dans de certaines limites nécessaires– une libre discussion.
The Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Co., Ltd.
Monsieur le Directeur de l'Egyptian Gazette.

Sachant combien vous aves à cœur la défense des intérêts du public alexandrin, je me fais un devoir de vous prier de vouloir bien donner l'hospitalité dans votre journal, du contrat relatif à la construction du chemin de fer entre Alexandrie et Ramleh, passé entre le Siear Edward Fairman et le Gouvernement Egyptien le 6 Août 1860.
Le voici dans toute sa teneur:
CONTRAT RELATIF A LA CONSTRUCTION D'UN CHEMIN DE FER ENTRE ALEXANDRIA TRAM
Entre les soussignés
S. E. Chérif Pacha, Ministre des Affaires
a été arrêté et stipulé ce qui suit:

Art 1er. Le Sieur Fairman est autorisé à construire d'après le plan conservé au Ministère des Affaires Étrangères et annexé aux présentes conventions, un Chemin de fer entre Alexandrie et Ramleh, avec faculté d'établir sur toute la ligne concédée, un télégraphe électrique. Tous frais de construction et d'entretien ou autres concernant les dits Chemins de Fer et télégraphes demeureront exclusivement at, à la charge du Sr. Fairman.

Art. 2- Le Sr. Fairman aura la jouissance gratuite des terrains appartenant au Gouvernement et qui seront occupés par l'entreprise; quant aux terrains appartenant à des particuliers, il devra s'entendre avec leurs propriétaires et fournir au Gouvernement avant l'ouverture des travaux, nt la preuve écrite qu'aucun d'eux ne s'oppose aux dits travaux sans que le gouvernement ait à intervenir en quoi que ce soit en dans les arrangements qui seront pris à cet e, égard dont toute la responsabilité icomax bera au Sr. Fairman, qui sera d'ailleurs T. tenu d'acquitter les charges et impôts auxquels les dits terrains, ainsi que les constructions y élevées, seront assujettis , d'après lois locales.

Art. 3.-Les routes, fortifications, ou jaunâtres lieux destinés, à un service public, que la voie ferrée aurait à traverser dans de son parcours, devront être maintenus en- entièrement libres par le Sieur Fairman au moyen de route-levis ou autres travaux et d'art, propres à assurer le passage de la voje, sans aucun dérangement dans la disposition actuelle des lieux.
ART. 4-Le Sieur Fairman transporters le personnel avez bagage et matériel du Gouvernement Egyptien pour la moitié des prix qui seront fixés par le tarif.
Les dépêches du Gouvernement et de tout autre Gouvernement seront transmises par priorité sur toutes autres et d'après l'ordre de leur remise à la station télégraphique.

Le Gouvernement égyptien jouira pour ses dépêches d'une réduction de moitié sur à le tarif applicable aux dépêches comme telles qui seront expédiées d'après l'ordre de leur remise à la station, et sauf l'application du paragraphe précédent.

Art. 5-La construction du Chemin de fer et de la ligne télégraphique devra être terminée au plus tard dans deux ans, à partir de la date du présent contrat. Fant d'exécution complète dans le terme prescrit, la concession sera considérée comme nulle et le Sieur Fairman pourra être contraint, au gré du Gouvernement, soit de rendre les lieux par lui occupés entièrement libres C dans le délai qui sera jugé nécessaire, soit de laisser l'entreprise avec tous ses acces soires au dit Gouvernement, moyennant une indemnité fixée à dire d'experts qui seront nommés d'accord entre les parties et prendront pour base de leur estimation les frais pour la construction des travaux.

Art. 6.-La présente concession est exclusivement personnelle au Sieur Fairman sans aucun privilège comme sans aucune garantie de la part du Gouvernement. Le dit Gouvernement pourra retirer cette on- cession à toute époque, avant comme après l'exécution des travaux, sauf dans tous les cas à indemniser le Sieur Fairman de travaux exécutés à dire d'experts, ainsi qu'il est expliqué à l'art. 5, et sans préjudice de la faculté réservée au Gouvernement faute d'exécution, complète dans le terme fixé par ce dernier article.
Ainsi fait en deux originaux, l'an pour être conservé aux archives du Ministère des Affaires Étrangères, l'autre pour être remis à Monsieur Fairman. Alexandrie, le six août 1860.
Approuvé, signé : CHÉRIF PACHA.
E. St. Jons Fairman.

L'autorisation faisant l'objet du Contrat ci-dessus a été transférée à une Compagnie Anglaise à capital illimité qui s'est constituée en dernier lieu à capital limité sous le nom de Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Company Ltd." à la date du 28 Juin 1883. Il résulte de ce contrat à l'évidence que la concussion accordée au Sieur Fairman, comprend une jouissance gratuite, laquelle en date du 28 juin 1888 a été transférée à l'Alexandria and Raleh Railway Company Limited.
Il resulte de ce contrat sera relevé très facilement en outre, qu'il ne s'agit ni d'un monopole, ni d'une concession indéfinie,

Par conséquent le Comité en formation pour la défense des intérêts des habitants de Ibrahimieh et de Ramleh, s'occupera sous peu et après avoir recueilli tous les 4 documents concernant is transformation de la traction à vapeur en traction électrique, de soumettre à l'approbation de nos gouvernants les conditions pouvant assurer la régularité d'un transport de voyageurs aussi important et touchant à tant d'in- térêts vitaux.
Avec mes remerciements, je vous présente, Monsieur le Directeur, l'expression de ma sincère considération. A. Stross.

div.head: Seance de la Commission Municipale
div.p: La séance projetée pour le 2 novembre 1904 n'ayant pu avoir lieu faute du nombre voulu de membres, une nouvelle séance de la Commission Municipale aura lieu le lundi 7 novembre 1904, à 4 h. p.m, très précises au palais municipal, selon le même ordre du jour.
Il sera délibéré valablement quel que soit le nombre des membres présents.

Cane Forts are firm. 1,200 bags Crystallized Trinidad sold at 19s.

BEETROOT-The speculative market on baying orders, both here and from the Continent, ales absence of sellers, opened firm, and prices advanced Xto the extent of 1/2d. Subsequently the markes be a came quieter, and the improvement was lost, bot, fer a good bars, closes steady at 1/4d above last night's prices, November sold as land buyers, December 11e 1 1/2 and sellers, Jan-March 11 8 1/4 to 11 8d and value, May 11s 5d to 11s 5 1/4d to 11s 4 3/4d and sellers, August 11 7d to 11s 6 3/4 and buyers f o b Hemberg.

INDIARUBBER.-The market for Para is very firm and prices are higher. Fine hard on the spot sellers at 5s. A good business has been done for. ward, including 5 tons fine hard November delivery at 4s 11 1/4d and buyers, 5 tons December at 4s 10d, 5 tons February at 4s 8 1/4d, and 5 tons Soft fine November at 4s 9 1/2d.
The receipts at Para to date amount to 2820 tons.

IVORY.-Egyptian: Alexandrian, Sudan and Tripoli in large supply, and mostly good quality. Soft te th 81 to 101 dearer, especially medium sizes; bangles and small teeth advanced about the same. Scrivelloes about 3l to 4l higher. Hard teeth 6l to 8l dearer. Scrivelloes 3l to 4l higher.

The quantities brought forward were: 17 tons Zanzibar, Abyssinian, Bomba, Mozambique and Siam 19 1/2 tons Egyptian, Alexan Irian ad Malta. 9 tons West Coast Africa, Angola, Gaboon, Nigar &c. 3/4 ton Bengae's from Lisbon 3 tons land carriage and indirect import. 2 tons sea horse teeth, boars' tasks and walrus teeth. 3 ons waste.

Of which, in addition to the 3 1/4 tons land carriage and indirect goods, 7 tous wore ex sale lots, viz, 1/4 ton East Indian, 8 1/4 tons Egyptian, 1/2 ton West Coast African, 2 1/2 tons land carriage, and 1/4 ton waste.
1 ¼ tons were bought in, viz, 1 ton Egyptian, son land carriage.

div.head: MR. DUPUIS' REPORT.
THE GASH SCHEME
div.byline: By Sir Hanbury Brown, K.C.M.G., late Inspector-General of Irrigation in Lower Egypt, and formerly in Upper Egypt.
div.p: (Concluded)

The question is: How can the Atbara be made to contribute to the irrigation of these plains of rich soil! It is not an easy matter to break such a river into the harness of irrigation. In the first place, it is decidedly torrential and excessively muddy secondly, it persistently flows in a narrow deep valley far below the level of the surrounding country and, thirdly, the natural features do not appear to afford the slightest facility for leading canals off it at any part of its course. Possibly a more perfect knowledge of the river and its surroundings may suggest some way of getting useful work out of it, at any rate in the nature of flood irrigation.

The flood of the Atbara commences to flow into the Nile at the end of June. It attains its maximum in August, when its tail discharge is estimated to be at least 2,500 cubic meter a second, during September it falls rapidly, and by the end of November it is practically dry. The total annual discharge of the river may be roughly estimated as at least 2000 million cubic metres.

Mr Dupuis makes the following suggestions: The only chance of producing a really satisfactory work would appear to consist in the construction of a masonry dam of very large proportions, the greater portion of the height of which would consist merely of a solid obstruction raising the water of the river much above its present level, and so enabling a canal to take off at a height that would greatly reduce the length of the expensive and difficult supply channel, combined with a reservoir super- structure to store water for the supply of the canal during the summer months. The expense of constructing such a work would be very great, but the section of the river valley would provide an efficient and suitable reservoir with large capacity."
Mr. Dupuis names Kashim-el-Girba as a place where a good site for such a dam is known to exist.

Sir W. Garstin does not include any work on the Atbars in his programme of works to be carried out, but fourth in his list of projects requiring study comes the Ka-him-el-Girba Dam, and sixth on the list comes the storage reservoirs on the Upper Atbara. As there is at present no information concerning the latter, any discussion of the proposal would be premature.

Lastly, we find, under the heading of "the Sun the statement of the approximate anal returns from taxation crediting the revenue with LE 1000 resulting from a tax of PT on 20 acres of "Land in the Nile Valley, north of Khartoum." But in the expenditure statement there is no figure given for the cost of works required to produce this revenue. The following passage in Sir W. Garstin's report explains this credit item, but not how the revenue is to be obtained without initial expenditure. Perhaps it is proposed to give grants of land, and to leave it to the new owners to carry out, at their own cost, the works necessary to bring the lands into cultivation-

"As regards the valley to the north of Khartoum and between that place and Berber, the conditions are entirely different from those of the Blue Nile, and more nearly resemble those of Upper Egypt and of the Dongola Pro- vince. The rainfall is irregular, being limited, even south of Shendy, to heavy but local storms. The strip of good land on either side of the river bounded by the desert is not very wide. In this region the best plan to follow for improving these lands is undoubtedly the erection of large pumping stations capable of irrigating a large area of the country. In addition, certain selected tracks might advantageously be turned into basins, but the expenditure would be heavy in proportion to the result to be obtained. The general conditions prevailing in Egypt, between Assouan and Assiout, would thus be reproduced, and the fact that this area throughout its entire length is traversed by a line of railway would greatly facilitate its agricultural development."

These lands would draw their water from the united Nile below Khartoum, and so would be grouped with Dongola and Egypt as regards the sources of their summer supply; as, I presume, the pumping stations would be intended for summer irrigation.

From the foregoing examination of Sir W. Garstin's proposals, it appears that the White Nile system is capable, with scientific handling, of providing a sufficient supply of water for the full development of the cultivable area of Egypt without sacrificing the needs of river navigation: sufficient also for that portion of the Sudan north of Khartoum-including the province of Dongola-which must depend for its water supply upon the united Nile below the junction of the White and Blue Niles.

As for the rest of the Sudan, the Blue Nile can certainly reclaim a considerable area of waste land to cultivation, probably about two million acres. But so little has been learnt) about the Blue Nile itself and its affluents that the possibilities are unknown. Nor has the area of land which would be cultivable, if water could only be brought to its surface, been so much as guessed at in the report, but probably it is not less than the whole of cultivated Egypt. It seems not unlikely that the area which could be cultivated, if irriga- tion could be given to it, is greater than the available water supply in the Sudan could satisfy, unless there is devised some method of storing water during flood which will overcome the tendency of the silt-laden waters to obliterate the basin of the reservoir.

The report that has been reviewed, itself repeats again and again that more information and more studies are required before any definite project can be prepared. But whatever may still remain to be done to complete the knowledge necessary to this end, the report makes a long stride in the required direction, and Sir William Garstin is to be congratulated on having put together, from a wealth of interesting material collected by himself and his staff, a most valuable account of a country hitherto little known, and never before reported upon by an irrigation expert with a personal knowledge of the country described. The Blue-book has already aroused great interest; and all who are proud of the Irrigation Service in Egypt will welcome it as the announcement of the birth of a sister Service in the Sudan, and will wish her "Good luck" and a future record of achievements as creditable and satisfactory as that of which her elder sister of Egypt can boast.

div.head: Our Paris Letter.
div.p: Everywhere, in diplomacy and out of it, the feeling and the strong hope are expressed that the negotiations between London and St. Petersburg may end with the satisfaction of British honour, and without the drawing of the sword. In the highest circles I have met the fear that danger may come from the known lack of coordination and organisation of the Russian Government. What the Tsar and Count Lamsdorff, both of whom are credited with most pacific sentiments, will desire, may not represent the opinion of the dominant party at the Court at the moment. Certain of the newspapers took a tone of sharpened criticism this morning against the English nation for its outspoken burst of indignation and resentment at what appears to the public. mind as official dallying. But I cannot observe that this carping spirit represents the real attitude of this people against its partner in the entente. There is nearly everywhere a feeling of real sympathy with England, and a desire to see a speedy end to the incident so menacing to the peace of the world. Admiral Rodjestvensky's alleged statements that he espied Japanese torpedo-boats amongst the fishing fleet is not accepted in naval circles here as justification for opening fire without first ascertaining without doubt the nationality and intentions of the craft.

There is such a thing as repenting at leisure, and there are signs that a certain portion of the Republican camp is so affected in respect of Saturday's vote in the Chamber for the separation of Church and State. There is by no means unanimity as to the wisdom of the proposed dissolution; neither is it certain that the measure will be popular with the peasantry, once they have grasped its true import. That uncompromising enemy of the Government, M. Lucien Millevoye, remarked to a friend of mine yesterday, with reference to the vote: "This is a game of bluff. The Chamber has accepted the principle, but it will never proceed, either in the life-time of this Ministry or the next, to apply the law. The country would be bitterly opposed to it. Do you imagine that the peasant will enjoy the alter- native of either paying for the curé himself or depriving his kith and kin of clerical ministrations at times of baptism, marriage, and burial 1" But it is not necessary, as I have stated above, to go to the Opposition to learn the dangers of Disestablishment. More than one organ of Ministerial sympathies in the country has raised its voice against the ruth less policy of M. Combes

With the abyss of separation suddenly yawing their feet, what are the church- men and church women of France to do to preserve their existence as a Christian entity Quietly, secretly almost, the Church is organizing its resources. In every diocese and every parish societies are being formed which will undertake the sustenance of the clergy. These societies may be founded absolutely under the protection of the Associations law itself, such being permitted by the terms of the Act. Week by week the faithful will contribute their francs and their sons to the parochial and diocesan funds. In the richer parishes there will be no difficulty to provide for the support of the card and for the maintenance of the fable of the Church; in the poorer districts, however, the fight will be hard, and will, perhaps, result in whole communities being deprived of the regular spiritual ministrations of the clergy. The work of organization, too, is not easy in France, where the church- going population has had little experience of the self sacrifice and the self renunciation necessary for the upholding of a religious cult. As in other Latin countries, this work has been undertaken by the Government, so that the Church has almost come to have the aspect of a Government institution and her ministers that of functionaries. The payment of pew rents and the sale of cemetery lots in consecrated ground, such as form a large part of the income, of un- endowed churches in England and America, are unknown in France, where such means of "raising the wind" are quite opposed to Gallie ideas. The habit of giving regularly and substantially to church purposes will take time, therefore, to become rooted and grounded, and in the meantime great difficulties are to be expected. Unfortunately for the cause of religion in France, those difficulties and this call for sacrifice and for calm steadfast devotion to the Church come at a moment when the country is partially submerged under a wave of Free Thought and indifference. The abolition of Christian teaching in the schools has also robbed the Church and religion of its most precious auxiliary.

The Church must become more active, its followers more imbued with the apostolic spirit. The priest, no longer a functionary, will become an apostle and a preacher. He will carry the fiery cross of his faith through every part of France. The clergy will certainly be a less numerous body than heretofore. It is likely that parishes will be grouped in the rural parts, and that the priest will speed hither and thither on his bicycle (no longer regarded by the Vatican as the engine of the flesh and worldliness, but an instrument of usefulness for the Church), preaching in improvised chapels, rallying the faithful, baptising their children, carrying the paten and the chalice to the bedside of the dying. This is the future of the Church in France. Meanwhile, the Combes Ministry will not live forever, more especially if the Premier really dreams of replacing M. Loubet at the Elysée. Perhaps, under a milder régime, and under one that has a less strange conception of liberty of thought, the Church may come to new power and new influence in France. For the moment, however, the position is one of great difficulty and danger.

Why not another universal exhibition in Paris? The question is being discussed in various quarters. The last exhibition in 1900 largely failed because of the absence of the English. But since then the "entente cordiale" has exercised its beneficent sway and there is little reason to doubt a hearty British welcome of the project. There is the question of the date. 1920 has been mentioned, as it will mark the Jubilee of the present Republic. But that is a long time to look forward to. A better date still, in the view of many people, would be 1911-eleven years after the last exhibition. This has been the usual interval between the great national fairs. The last exhibition ended. in a species of fiasco, not merely because the best customers of France stayed away, but be- cause, to speak plainly, the exhibition was unworthy in certain of its aspects. No one wants a repetition of some of the objectionable side-shows, which flaunted themselves in the Rue de Paris under cosmopolitan auspices, but every one wants a fuller development of the real features the artistic and industrial exhibits: some return in fact to the dignity of the earliest of these enterprises, that, for instance, of 1855.

From final returns just issued by the Customs Department, the gross movement of the trade of France with her colonies and foreign countries in 1903, imports and exports combined, is estimated to have reached a total of £466,280,000, being an increase of £14,440,000 on the previous year, and £24,120,000 compared with the average of the quinquennial period prior to 1903.

The interesting controversy in England on "The Handicap of Marriage '' has its commentary on this side of the Channel. Woman has not begun to take that independent position here that she apparently has in England; nevertheless there is a "woman's question," and a "marriage question," none the less real because they are so seldom touched upon in the public press. Whilst the most casual observer is struck with the predominant part that woman plays in the industrial, social, and domestic concerns of the nation, her direct influence in politics or education is very small. Man has usurped the platform, and it is rarely that the other side of the question is heard at all. But no masculine voice has yet been raised to say that the education of the modern French woman unfits her to be the help-meet of man or imposes a handicap upon the husband. Such a contention would be so obviously untrue that no one is absurd enough to make it. Man is not handicapped by woman in France-the reverse is nearer the truth. In the

lower walks of life where questions of ways and means have to be carefully considered, the wife's "dot" not only brings important help to the husband, but it is often backed by her own practical wisdom and cautious economy in the business in which the capital of both is involved. Indeed, the instruction of women in all classes is inspired (if not in the school, at least out of it) by the thought that they will one day enter the marriage state. Except a certain extreme section, which has no influence on the mass of the sex, there is no breaking away from the traditional yoke. On the contrary, it is to be noted that the dowerless young women of the labouring classes are looking to marriage as their proper state in society rather than the unsanctioned union which has, hitherto, so often represented the domestic hearth.

There is no handicap of marriage in France. Rather is it that there is not handicap enough. The timidity of the young men in face of Hymen is the real disquieting feature of the social situation. Marriages take place later in France than in England, and their number per thousand is diminishing. The increasing difficulties of making a career in the over-crowded professions, the existence of the military service, retarding the age at which a man is in possession of a competency, the long years spent in the schools of the faculties and in merely the chrysalis state, and, finally, the smallness of the salaries paid, even for the most expert labour, are so many causes for the late marriage or for the state of celibacy. It may also be said that a contributory cause is the large number of women now employed in the French Post Office, who postpone their marriage until their salary has reached a certain figure.

The present moment is one of peculiar im- portance and interest in the education of French women. The Catholic school for the higher bourgeoisie has had to close its doors, under the operation of the Associations Law. In certain cases private schools have arisen in their place, but the private school is badly organized in France, and cannot, in any case, hope to compete with the State lycée. It may be taken for granted, therefore, that the girls of the upper middle classes in France will, in future, receive their education in a totally different "milieu" from heretofore. Instead of the priest and the sister, their teacher will be the highly trained, intelligent graduate of a nor- mal college. The result will be to place the girls on the same footing, intellectually, as their brothers. Then we may expect the "emancipation" for which some of their sisters in England cry.

With the re-opening of the Paris Law Courts, there comes the familiar breath of scandal- this time. affecting the Bar itself. A large number of persons are stated to be in custody on the charge of robbery committed in shops, and a group of more or less briefless barristers are stated to have approached these persons not only with offers of legal assistance at low fees, but with a guarantee of securing suspense of penalty under the First Offenders Act, for a higher fee. As the First Offenders Act applies automatically to all such cases, the taking of a fee would, of course, be sheer swindling. The Bar Council is stated to be investigating the affair.

The prisoner's thumb-mark is no longer regarded as the infallible guide to a man's identity that it once was. M. Bertillon, the father of the anthropometric system, has decided to take in future the impress of the ten fingers of the man. Thumbs, notwithstand. ing what has been said to the contrary, have a way of repeating themselves on different hands, with a consequent confusion in the minds of police authority.

In its own way, the new Parisian weekly, printed in white ink on black paper, and en- titled "The Invisible," must be admitted to be sufficiently strange, though it is not the first of its kind. As a journalistic curiosity it must run the gauntlet of comparison with a host of strangely varied newspapers. As long ago as 1840 Paris published a daily "Political Hand-P kerchief," which was printed on linen, and by passing through the wash was ready to justify its name in the pocket of the reader. In less than six months the publisher was compelled to abandon his enterprise, as the linen absorbed so much ink that it ran away with the profits. A tragic echo from the Franco German war is reported from Gundershofer, in Alsace. Two workmen were overhauling some old iron in the manufactory of M. Simon Dreyfus, when a shell, rusty but still, as the result proved, in all too efficient condition, exploded, carrying away a leg of one of the men, besides injuring him badly in the abdomen. The other sustained a fracture of the skull, from which he died shortly afterwards. A fragment of the shell crashed into the room. of a dwelling house where some children were at play, injuring one of them severely in the arm.

div.head:
SPORT AND PLAY.
FOOTBALL.
div.p: RAS-ELTIN SCHOOL. ET. C. The school started its fixtures for the season 1904-05 with the annual match against the E. T. C. From start to finish the game was a most pleasant one. Both sides displayed signs of lack of practice, but good play was shown. Mr. Hickling and Selim scored for the school and Mr. Byrne for the ET. C., the school winning a close game by 2 goals to 1. Bakir played a very good game at back, while all the school forwards were good. Mr. Byrne, of the ET. C., caught the eye most for the visiting team. Corpl. Murphy, of the Berks, refereed excellently.

La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de canalisation de la rue El Antaki. Le cautionnement est fix à L. E. 8. Le cahier des charges est déposé au Barreau de Ia Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressé tous les jours de 9h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 15 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention "Soumission pour canalisation de la rue el Antaki "
